title: If you are part of a credit union and file chapter 7 for your overdraft loan can they close your checking and savings?
question: As a part of a credit union I am concerned if I apply for chapter 7 and discharge my overdraft loan will they cancel my checking and savings account therefore no longer agreeing to bank with me?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Automatic stays in bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Car loan,Consumer protection
answers:
Credit Unions are membership organizations - or a "union" of interest. Almost all credit unions have a policy that if they experience any loss as a result of your bankruptcy, you may no longer be a member of that credit union and therefore may not have a share ( savings ) or a draft
(checking) account. If you reaffirm your debt, they will allow you to continue your membership in good standing including use of all deposit accounts. If you reaffirm and pay back the credit union, you may find they are still a good source of credit for you in the future.
Unfortunately, I've seen this very frequently in Southern California. It may be time to look for another banking institution in the area.

The nicest credit union is more vicious than the worst bank during a bankruptcy. On top of that, many consumer protection laws for banks exempt credit unions.

You should remove *all* money from a credit union before filing; unlike banks, they can sometimes offset the money in your accounts against your debts. They also tend to cross-collateralize your accounts; your car is probably collateral not only for your car loan, but for your credit card and overdraft line.

I don't believe that I have seen a case in the last few years in which the credit union did *not* close the checking account--there is generally a letter stating that it is their policy not to have such accounts from members from whom they suffered a loss. The share/savings account can generally stay open.

I agree with my colleagues that your CU will not have to continue to do business with you but feel compelled to point out that CUs have some special rules that allow them to offset any losses they incur due to a bankruptcy filing against any money that the person filing the bankruptcy has on deposit in their accounts at the time of the filing of the bankruptcy. In my district it is very common for a CU to take any money in a depository account to offset against any losses the CU will suffer as a result of your filing and because of the special rules that CUs enjoy, this is not a violation of the automatic stay and there is no way to force the return of the money. My advice when I have clients who are considering filing bankruptcy who are also CU members who owe money to their CU is to withdraw all but the minimum allowed to keep the account open , usually $25, prior to filing. But talk to your lawyer about this issue.

Short answer, yes.

With credit unions in particular, it is quite common for a CU to drop a customer if that customer files bankruptcy, especially if the customer discharged a debt owed to the CU.

Sorry, but as pointed out, bankruptcy merely prevents the collection of a debt.

Big picture, who cares. Go bank someplace else. The goal is to get financially fit by eliminating your debt; other banks and credit unions will do business with you.
Bankruptcy gets you a discharge, but it does not act to force businesses to do business with you in the future. Only your credit union can answer that question.

Hello,

I think the answer to your question depends on the credit union, and their specific rules. Unfortunately, it's be my experience that many credit unions tend to require you to reaffirm (ie. keep/repay) debts you owe them in order to continue to keep your accounts open/in good standing. A point to remember is credit unions are "membership" organizations, and not banks. As such... credit unions tend to have different and often more strict rules/restrictions. Ultimately, when you file your chapter 7, if you owe the credit union (due to unpaid overdraft fees), they will need to be included as a creditor. However, one way or another hopefully you will be able to work with them so that you can keep your accounts. I hope this info helps.
